title: Marriott Profit Fell 23% for Third Quarter
summary: Hotel company lowers its outlook for a key revenue metric; Hong Kong demonstrations limit growth. Marriott International Inc. reported a 23% drop in quarterly profit and lowered its view for a crucial metric in the hospitality industry, as growth in the hotel business cools off.

title: SEC Urged to End Ratings Firms' Conflicted Business Model
summary: An advisory panel is considering whether to recommend a new dynamic. A panel of academics and former credit-ratings-firm executives urged the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday to finally end the industry's "issuer pay" business model in which entities that sell bonds also pay for ratings.

title: McDonald's Top Human-Resources Officer Departs After CEO Firing
summary: Burger giant fired its chief executive, Steve Easterbrook, due to a relationship with an employee. McDonald's Corp. said its top human-resources executive has left the company, days after the burger giant fired its chief executive, Steve Easterbrook, because of his relationship with an employee.

title: Under Armour Shares Slide on News of Accounting Probe
summary: Executives say they have cooperated for more than two years and decline to discuss why probe wasn't disclosed. Under Armour Inc. shares fell nearly 19% after the company confirmed it was the subject of a federal investigation into its accounting practices.

title: Boris's Bad Campaign Start
summary: A ban on fracking is the wrong message for post-Brexit prosperity.. Boris Johnson last week wrung an early election from an unwilling Parliament, but he's off to a bad start for the Dec. 12 poll. The Prime Minister started things off by announcing a ban on hydraulic fracturing for oil and natural gas.

title: Where Wealth Taxes Failed
summary: Here's a lesson from Europe that Warren and Sanders ignore.. Bernie Sanders often points to Europe as his economic model, but there's one lesson from the Continent that he and Elizabeth Warren want to ignore. Europe has tried and mostly rejected the wealth taxes that the two presidential candidates are now promising for America.

title: State Pirates in the Dock
summary: The Justices hear a crucial case of copyright and state rights.. The Supreme Court has bolstered both state and property rights in recent decades, but on Tuesday it will mediate an ostensible conflict between the two. States argue they can't be sued for copyright infringement, but sovereign immunity isn't a constitutional license to steal intellectual property.

title: The Surprising Targets of Elizabeth Warren's Jobs Tax
summary: How long can she pretend she's only punishing billionaires?. Presidential candidate Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.) has become famous for advocating the abolition of private health plans covering more than 150 million Americans and the firing of two million Americans who work for such plans. But she didn't make clear until Friday that she intends to punish employers who have been providing workers with more health benefits than the law requires.

title: Vaping-Related Illnesses Remain a Mystery to New York Health Officials
summary: Hearing on vaping comes as Gov. Cuomo calls for ban on flavored e-cigarette products. More than 150 people in New York have been sickened by vaping-related illnesses, and state health regulators still don't understand what specifically is causing the ailments, according to a top state health official who testified before New York state senators on Monday.

title: Democrats Release Transcripts of Yovanovitch, McKinley Testimony
summary: Former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine said State Department officials didn't publicly support her out of fear President Trump would overrule them. WASHINGTON-The former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine said State Department officials didn't publicly support her out of fear of being overruled by President Trump, according to the transcript of her impeachment-inquiry testimony that revealed new details about the circumstances of her firing.

title: Auditors Look to Modernize Rules to Include Environmental, Social and Cybersecurity Issues
summary: Under rules proposed by standards board, auditors of private companies would be able to review nonfinancial issues without company first doing so. The auditing standards board of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants is working to modernize standards governing nonfinancial information to include cybersecurity and environmental, social and corporate governance issues.

title: Beijing Will Give You Cold War Nostalgia
summary: Nuclear deterrence was simple compared with the fluid nature of cyberwarfare.. America's 21st-century competition with China is likely to be more dangerous and more complex than its old Cold War with the Soviet Union. This is partly because China's economic power makes it a much more formidable and resourceful opponent than the U.S.S.R., and partly because the technological environment has changed so dramatically in the past generation.

title: Free Lori Loughlin
summary: The feds are treating the actress as if she and her husband were Bonnie and Clyde.. Here's hoping Lori Loughlin beats the rap.

title: Saudi Arabia Is Changing Fast
summary: Social liberalization has outpaced economic reform, but there doesn't seem to be any turning back.. Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

title: In Praise of Today's Entrepreneurs
summary: Fewer new businesses are starting, but minorities and women are founding more.. We're treading water. The most recent figures from the U.S. Census Longitudinal Business Database show America losing nearly as many businesses as are launched. In 2016, the most recent year for which data are available, roughly 433,000 businesses were born, and 400,000 died. The share of new firms as a percentage of total firms today hovers around 8%, much lower than the average "business birthrate" of 11% between 1980 and 2010. That's a big concern because new businesses are engines of innovation, job creation and economic growth.

title: Stop the States' Copyright Plunder
summary: They claim protection for their own intellectual property while engaging in blatant piracy.. If you took a photo and Harvard put it on its website without permission, you could sue the university for copyright infringement and win. Not if the University of Texas did the same thing. The Supreme Court has a chance to end the double standard that allows state institutions to run roughshod over copyrights, the legal fountainhead of American creativity.

title: Warren Asks What the Country Can Do for You
summary: She proposes 'Medicare for All' but fears voters will be unwilling to pay anything at all for it.. Elizabeth Warren's release Friday of a more specific health-care platform only raised more questions about Medicare for All and its effects on the middle class. Conservatives as well as Ms. Warren's Democratic opponents questioned the assumptions behind her claim that she can enact a single-payer plan without raising taxes on the middle class. Yet the harshest critic may be Ms. Warren herself. "Ask not what your country can do for you-ask what you can do for your country," John F. Kennedy, who once held Ms. Warren's Senate seat, urged. She refuses to ask the middle class to pay a dime for her costly proposal.

title: 'The Life of Guy' Review: Pronoun Pyrotechnics
summary: Americans have abandoned the British ritual of burning "papist" conspirator Guy Fawkes in efﬁgy, but his name remains on our tongues.. The name Guy Fawkes is resonant in Britain. Only a vague notion of the man himself endures, but each November his celebrity is reaffirmed, as febrile festivities mark his involvement in one of history's most audacious anti-authoritarian plots. Fawkes was not, as commonly imagined, its ringleader. That role belonged to Robert Catesby, a charismatic member of England's Catholic gentry, which found itself, in a predominantly Protestant society, penalized for its beliefs. Catesby wanted to destroy the entire machinery of government. Yet it was one of his recruits who was found, shortly after midnight on Nov. 5, 1605, in a cellar beneath London's House of Lords, guarding a pile of brushwood that concealed a hoard of explosives.

title: Notable & Quotable: Twitter's Political Ad Ban
summary: 'Dorsey says that he wants to level the playing field. Perhaps he, with 4.2 million followers, should shadow-ban himself.'. Bradley A. Smithwriting for City Journal, Nov. 1:

title: Shake Shack Warns of Slower Growth
summary: Shares fell 15% in after-hours trading after the New York-based burger chain cut its forecast for comparable-store sales. Shake Shack Inc. disappointed investors after warning that sales are going to be weaker this fiscal year than it had previously anticipated.

title: Supreme Court Explores Suspended-License Traffic Stop
summary: In Kansas case, justices ask if it is reasonable to assume that drivers with suspended licenses continue to drive. WASHINGTON-Is it common sense to assume that drivers with suspended licenses keep driving their cars anyway? That question occupied the Supreme Court on Monday, as the justices examined a 2016 traffic stop in Lawrence, Kan., that was conducted solely because the registered owner had his license revoked.

title: Dow Hits a Record as U.S. Stocks Are Outpacing World
summary: Steady consumer spending and strength in the labor market keep supporting U.S. stocks despite fears of a recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed Monday to its first record since mid-July, the latest example of investors' faith in the domestic economy powering U.S. stocks to fresh highs.

title: A Former Star Returns to the Mets. This Time to Manage.
summary: Carlos Beltrán had a Hall of Fame-caliber career. He is back in New York as a manager. Will it work?. A year after they hired an agent as their general manager, the New York Mets made another move this weekend that surprised the baseball world: They chose Carlos Beltrán to serve as their next manager, formally unveiling him Monday morning at a news conference at Citi Field.

title: Salt Lake Tribune Becomes a Nonprofit
summary: Utah's largest newspaper's new status highlights considerable challenges facing local news outlets. The Salt Lake Tribune, the largest newspaper in Utah, is becoming a nonprofit, marking a new approach in a struggling industry seeking new business models to stay afloat.

summary: Online marketplace for used luxury goods reported a 55% increase in revenue from a year ago. The RealReal Inc. reported a jump in quarterly revenue and shoppers on its marketplace but the online seller of luxury goods continues to lose money.

summary: Multinationals like Coca-Cola, Adidas and HP reuse trash fished from seas or collected on coastlines. Companies seeking to cut plastic use are tapping a vast source of raw materials: ocean garbage.

summary: Steve Easterbrook's successor will struggle to maintain the fast-food company's impressive performance as economic forces move against it. It is always interesting how a company's shares react when the boss departs unexpectedly, and the case of McDonald's is more telling than most.

summary: Carrier lost 91,000 postpaid phone connections in latest quarter; revenue fell. Sprint Corp. lost 91,000 of its most lucrative phone connections in the latest quarter, as the No. 4 U.S. carrier struggled to retain subscribers and compete with its larger rivals for new customers.

summary: Gene therapy has successfully been used to treat age-related ailments in mice. Now it's being studied in dogs.. North Grafton, Mass.

summary: All three major U.S. stock indexes end at new highs. Fresh optimism over trade drove U.S. stocks to records Monday, extending the market's recent rally.

summary: The department suggests the writer of a forthcoming book risks violating nondisclosure agreement. title: 'J.M.W. Turner: Watercolors From Tate' Review: Endlessly Inventive
summary: The largest selection of Turner watercolors to be seen in the U.S. for decades shows that the artist didn't need oil paint to be a master of luminosity and action..

title: Assure That Automation Helps the Workers
summary: Already, blockchain companies are moving overseas. We need to do everything we can to keep these groundbreaking projects in the U.S.. "The High Cost of Impeding Automation" (Journal Report, Oct. 25) raises salient points. American entrepreneurs dominate the global economy because they take risks to innovate existing products and services. If we allow fear to stifle their efforts, we risk surrendering global superiority and sacrificing improvements in quality of living-just to preserve the status quo. This was evident when the House Financial Services Committee questioned Mark Zuckerberg last month. While I share some of my colleagues' skepticism about Facebook's Libra project, I find their fear of blockchain and cryptocurrency shortsighted. Already, blockchain companies are moving overseas, where countries such as Switzerland have the regulatory framework to support innovation while protecting consumers. We need to do everything we can to keep these groundbreaking projects in the U.S. by establishing a clear regulatory framework that protects American innovators, investors and consumers.

title: Where Was California's PUC in Years Past?
summary: Although the politicians bear much responsibility for the PG&E debacle, the California Public Utilities Commission should be asked why it didn't do its job.. Regarding Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.'s "Revolutionary California" (Business World, Oct. 30): There is not an electric-utility executive who doesn't say to himself or herself every night, "There but by the grace of God go I," when they look at the mess in California, particularly as it relates to PG&E . Although the politicians bear much responsibility for the PG&E debacle, the California Public Utilities Commission should be asked why it didn't do its job.

title: A Wealth Tax Could Hold All Institutions Responsible
summary: A more balanced approach to policy formulation would consider the broader context of our very mixed political economy, rather than scapegoating the private business sector.. Daniel Henninger makes a good point about presidential candidates showing very little awareness or appreciation of the private sector ("The Democrats' Spooky Politics," Wonder Land, Oct. 31). Apart from the merits of their critiques, it's also notable that their focus within the private sector is limited to businesses even though nowadays private nonprofits would share many of the characteristics they find objectionable. For instance, why shouldn't a wealth tax apply to the most extraordinary endowments of colleges, private foundations and cultural organizations? And for the many highly regulated industry sectors, shouldn't accountability be shared by the federal and state regulators overseeing those businesses?

title: Be Realistic in Expectations for Helping the Homeless
summary: If you live in a tent on the street or under an overpass, you are not looking for a cheap apartment, you likely have a mental-health or addiction issue and couldn't afford any apartment, no matter how little it costs.. Regarding the letters of Oct. 10 and Oct. 12 on the homeless in California: If you live in a tent on the street or under an overpass, you are not looking for a cheap apartment, you likely have a mental-health or addiction issue and couldn't afford any apartment, no matter how little it costs. Politicians talk about affordable housing for most street residents, but this is completely unrealistic.

title: Employees Aren't Children but Parenting Skills Help
summary: Mike Vance said: "The superlative mother doesn't do annual performances with her children.". "How Parenting Books Taught Me to Be a Better Leader" (Journal Report, Oct. 28) reminds me of advice I heard in the mid-1980s from creative-thinking guru Mike Vance. Vance, who is credited with popularizing the phrase "think out of the box," was speaking about performance evaluations, and he cited the "superlative mother" as the model for managers. As I recall, Vance said: "The superlative mother doesn't do annual performances with her children. She provides immediate evaluations when necessary." Just one more lesson from good parenting.

title: New York Fed Official Says Market Interventions Have Restored Calm
summary: Lorie Logan, who is the acting leader of the Markets Desk at the New York Fed, said efforts are working well. The New York Fed's efforts to calm short-term markets and keep them placid is working well, a top central bank staffer said Monday.

summary: Two albums reveal fresh classical-music directions for a familiar instrument..

title: How Ugg Finally Got Men Into Its Fuzzy Boots
summary: And it's not just the much-mocked booties. Through social media marketing and new styles from lace-ups to sneakers, the brand has finally made headway with male consumers.. AS RECENTLY AS 2016, ads pushing Uggs for men showed New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady loafing indoors in the brand's cozy shearling-lined slippers, looking barely awake and exuding little energy. These days, you won't find Mr. Brady's mellow smirk anywhere in the 41-year-old company's New York City showroom. Instead, much livelier imagery sits alongside displays of the fuzz-filled boots. One framed photo captures Kofi Siriboe, a Ghanian actor with nearly a million Instagram followers, bounding down a city street dressed entirely in red, save for the beige Uggs on his feet. In another, Migos rapper Offset kicks out his leg as he exits an SUV-an Ugg logo clearly visible on his boot's sole.

title: Coal Plants Would Get More Flexibility on Waste in EPA Proposal
summary: Utility operators' group welcomes proposal to give power plants more time to keep using unlined coal-ash waste ponds. WASHINGTON-The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday proposed easing 2015 rules for disposing of coal ash and wastewater from coal-fired power plants.

title: The Patriots, the Quarterbacks and the NFL Season's Big Questions
summary: After a historic first half of the season, the Patriots defense finally broke against the Ravens on Sunday night. title: Miami's Preeminent Collector Family Expands Their Museum
summary: The Rubell family, collectors for 55 years, have had a museum space in Miami's Wynwood since 1993-but their new location blossoms in size and scope. Mera and Don Rubell bought their first piece of art when they were newlyweds in 1964. It was a drawing they purchased, on a $25-a-month installment plan, from a minor New York artist on a visit to his squat. "That experience really taught us how to spend time with artists in their studios," says Mera, 76. "That's how our lives of collecting began."

title: The 20 Best-Designed Items of November
summary: From a cabana-striped chair to a dark-stone "gua sha" tool, the chicest items of fall, according to our editors. Now he's started his own brand of housewares and accessories, called Lateral Objects, to bring his style home. The collection offers a range of playful, useful items, from pop-inspired towels in mesh pouches ($195/set) to textured rubber coasters ($40 for four) to handmade gradient glasses in tropical colors ($40 each). lateralobjects.com

title: Can Riccardo Tisci Propel Burberry Beyond Gabardine?
summary: Fearless Italian designer Riccardo Tisci dresses rappers and royalty alike. But can his street-inspired style propel $10.5 billion brand Burberry-a company as British as Buckingham Palace?. In every hard story, you find the romance," says Riccardo Tisci. He is talking about Thomas Burberry, a self-made, tough Victorian who established his clothing company, Burberry, in 1856 at the age of 21. And yet, Tisci, 45, who became Burberry's chief creative officer last year, could just as easily be talking about himself.

title: Under Armour Is Subject of Federal Accounting Probes
summary: Justice Department, SEC examining how sportswear maker recorded revenue; company says it is cooperating with investigators. Federal authorities are investigating Under Armour Inc.'s accounting practices in a probe examining whether the sportswear maker shifted sales from quarter to quarter to appear healthier, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: The President Enters the Octagon
summary: UFC 244 features a contentious main event-and a historic visit from President Trump. Sometimes, a moment happens that feels so current, so urgently now, so comically representative of the times we now live in, you almost can't believe it.

title: China's Country Banks Sing the Blues
summary: A bank run in Henan province reignited fears about the country's shaky small lenders. Faced with a bank run, a rural lender in China's Henan province last week resorted to piling stacks of bills behind teller windows and recruiting state employees to ostentatiously deposit cash.

title: The Pot Industry Is Scrambling for Cash
summary: Slump in cannabis companies' equity value is a big problem for them. A sharp drop in their stock-market valuations will have an outsize impact on cannabis companies. Deal making is already slowing, while debt is becoming scarce and more expensive.

title: Brooklyn Academy of Music Set to Open Art Gallery
summary: Cultural center is set to open the Rudin Family Gallery, featuring work by contemporary artists. Its name may suggest otherwise, but the Brooklyn Academy of Music is establishing a bigger foothold in the art world.

title: Once a Problem Child, the Dreamliner Keeps Boeing Afloat
summary: Inflows of cash from the once-troublesome 787 Dreamliner are now sustaining the production of the grounded 737 MAX. In a twist of fate, Boeing 's financial health through the 737 MAX crisis will rely heavily on what was once another problem child: the 787 Dreamliner.

title: Uber Faces Earnings Test Ahead of Lockup Expiration
summary: Ride-hailing company is under pressure to show it can generate sustainable profits. Uber Technologies will report earnings after the market closes on Monday. Here are the key points:

title: A U.S.-China Trade Deal Won't Rescue Emerging Market Stocks
summary: What is happening in the slowing Chinese domestic economy matters far more for the MSCI EM index than the latest mood on tariffs.

title: Large Bitcoin Player Manipulated Price Sharply Higher, Study Says
summary: 'Stablecoin' tether, Bitfinex exchange reportedly used to drive up cryptocurrency's price in 2017 and 2018. A single large player manipulated the price of bitcoin as it ran up to a peak of nearly $20,000 two years ago, a new study concludes.

title: After 150 Years, Navajo Win Back Political Power in Utah
summary: Resume Subscription. MONTICELLO, Utah-Navajo people managed their affairs for centuries in the spectacular buttes and mesas of what is now San Juan County, Utah, until white settlers moved in and established political and economic control here nearly 150 years ago.

title: Roger Stone Trial Likely to Be a Spectacle
summary: Longtime Trump associate is charged with lying and attempted obstruction. The criminal trial of Trump associate Roger Stone is to begin Tuesday in Washington, one of the last loose ends stemming from special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

title: Santander Takes Stake in U.K. Payments Company
summary: Spanish lender to buy just over 50% of Ebury for $453 million. Spanish bank Banco Santander SA agreed to acquire a stake in a U.K.-based payments platform for £350 million ($453 million), as European banks hobbled by ultralow interest rates target growth areas.

title: Private-Equity Executives Throw Weight Into 2020 Elections
summary: As their industry is heaped with criticism, private-equity CEOs spend millions to influence political races. Private-equity executives are playing a familiar role in political races unfolding across the country: spending big to defend their industry's interests.

title: Japanese Princeling's Goal to Ditch Coal Hits a Snag: He's Environment Minister Now
summary: Shinjiro Koizumi is being tested as he attempts to wean the country from its dependence on coal power. YOKOSUKA, Japan-Shinjiro Koizumi has led a charmed existence since he entered Japan's Parliament a decade ago, taking over a seat held by his father, former Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.

title: Why No-Cost ETFs Aren't No Cost
summary: ETF sticker prices are sinking. But don't let cheap trading dictate your decisions, or forget the other costs that are harder to see.. Online brokerages are dangling a new temptation in front of investors: the near-obliteration of trading commissions. That's right, buy or sell any stock or exchange-traded fund and pay nothing!

title: What Stock-Market Investors Should Know About Presidential Cycles
summary: The strong market in 2019 is what's expected in the third year of any president's term, says Jeffrey Hirsch of Stock Trader's Almanac. The election will determine the next pattern.. More than any investor alive today, Jeffrey Hirsch was born, bred, weaned and raised on stock-market cycles, patterns, seasonality data, charts and trends.

title: The Real Impact of Tax-Loss Harvesting-and What Investors Should Do About It
summary: The impact can be pretty significant, especially in years when stocks have done well. Toward the end of each year, investors clamor to reduce their tax bills by selling "loser" stocks, or those that have experienced negative capital gains. This practice is referred to as tax-loss harvesting.

title: Low-Volatility Funds Are in Demand, Once Again
summary: Investors turn to ETFs and mutual funds that buy low-volatility stocks as a way to hedge against market volatility. The stock market's turmoil over the past year has sent many investors scurrying for safety. And they have been pouring money into "low-volatility" stock funds.

title: Small-Cap Stocks Might Not Be Hit By the Usual End-of-Year Blues
summary: Year-end large/small trend for stocks is shaping up differently this time. Fortunately for investors in the smallest stocks, the last two months of this year may not be as depressing as they usually are.

title: Private Equity Might Be Going Downscale. Should You Invest?
summary: As the SEC considers allowing the masses to invest in private-equity funds, here's what to know. A bigger world of investing could soon open up for small investors.

title: Why Investors Might Want to Bet on Humble CEOs
summary: A study suggests that analysts underestimate the earnings potential of companies run by modest leaders. Humble CEOs don't inspire much confidence among financial analysts-but that might be good news for people who invest in the CEOs' companies.

title: What Investors Can Learn From the Best Poker Players
summary: For one thing, don't be more willing to walk away when you've won money than when you've lost it. Some of the biggest investors on Wall Street are known to be ace poker players. Are there things we small fish can learn from Texas Hold 'em that will make us better investors?

title: What Is 'Investor Positioning'?
summary: Knowing how bullish or bearish professional investors are can provide a hint at possible market movements. Little sparks the interest of investors more than insight into where the market will move next. That's why you will hear Wall Street pros talk about "investor positioning." In the simplest terms, it refers to readings of whether professional investors are collectively bullish or bearish on a particular asset class. At certain times, these readings can help signal a future move in prices.

title: U.S.-Stock Funds Rose 1.7% in October
summary: Year-to-date gain of 20% sets investors up for a complete turnaround from a bad 2018. Stocks are on a roll, despite everything swirling around them, and fund investors aren't complaining.

title: Funds Stick With Stocks of Gun Companies
summary: Even as growing numbers of investors snub gun makers, funds own significant numbers of their shares. U.S.-based open-end mutual funds and exchange-traded funds own nearly a third of the stock in America's two publicly traded gun companies, even as many investors are snubbing those shares.

title: Marijuana ETFs Drag Despite the Interest in Them
summary: Fund flows are strong for marijuana-related ETF investments, but bracing year-to-date declines range from 45% to 26%. The number of marijuana-related ETFs launched in the U.S. has grown in 2019, and the appetite remains high-despite their underperformance as investments.

title: Asia-Pacific Nations Move Closer to Signing China-Backed Trade Pact
summary: Agreement would bring together 16 countries that make up nearly half the world's population. Thailand said negotiations have concluded for a sprawling China-backed regional trade agreement, bringing 16 Asia-Pacific countries involved in the talks closer to signing the pact.

title: Before 737 MAX Returns to Service, Airlines Plan to Show It Is Safe
summary: U.S. carriers to make jet's initial flights without passengers to shore up confidence of pilots, customers. Airlines aren't leaving it to Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration to reassure travelers the 737 MAX will be safe to fly. They are devising plans to conduct their own demonstration flights with senior company officials on board to amplify that message.

title: Protesters Attack Iranian Consulate in Iraqi City
summary: Incident in Karbala marks growing anger over Tehran's involvement in the country's affairs. Iraqi protesters attacked the Iranian consulate in the city of Karbala, in the latest sign of mounting anger against Tehran's involvement in the country's affairs.
